Sentence: I do not consider myself someone who “supports GMO”, just like I also don’t consider myself someone who “supports chemistry”, or “supports electricity”.
These are all just tools and technologies that can be applied in both good or bad ways.
Stop focusing on the screwdriver.

Start focusing on what people are *doing* with the screwdriver… Likewise, one would have to be a real Luddite to call oneself “anti-electricity” - or be very poorly informed about what electricity is and all the many positive ways it can be used.
Same goes for “anti-GMO”.

This is also why so many scientists object to labeling foods as GMO or GMO-free: it’s essentially a meaningless label because it carries zero information about *what* modification was made to the food.
Might as well label food as “made with electricity”, or “contains no chemicals” (fact check: *everything* is made out of chemicals).
For the current commercial GMO crops, there are essentially no health reasons to choose in favor or against GMO crops just because they are GMO.

There are definitely some strong environmental and agro-political reasons to choose crops that have been grown in ways that reduce the use of dangerous chemicals, or crops grown by local family farms vs a giant industrial agrocomplex, or heirloom varieties vs monocultures, or to eat lower on the food chain; but those are not issues that are specific to the GMO vs non-GMO debate.
I would be more than happy to eat a genetically engineered heirloom tomato grown organically by a local family farm, if I could find such a thing…
I'm not your doctor, so whether you actually have all these conditions or not is not for me to say.
Since they are more likely to be fertilized with manure, and less likely to be cleaned properly, they also are covered in bad microbes!
Consider this: health nuts love organic, anti-oxidant rich food, right?
Over 150 such health nuts got Hepatitis A in 2013 from "Townsend Farms Organic Antioxidant Blend."

( FDA Investigates Multistate Outbreak of Hepatitis A Illnesses Associated with Pomegranate seeds from Turkish Importer ) Hepatitis is spread by human feces: I'll take my chances with man-made chemicals before eating someone else's s**t. What does the science say?
It's actually not as extreme as me: Two studies covering decades of work both found the risk of food poisoning is the same for organics and conventional food.
No higher or lower.
Again, the terms have no meaning or impact on health .
But given that organics are more expensive and have no benefit (proven in the 2012 Stanford study), I see no reason to waste money on them.
Like I say in my answer, every product must be evaluated independently.
There is no such thing as "toxins" because even those probiotics you take can have harsh side effects at high doses (namely diarrhea, your body's way of flushing out excess microbes).
Plus, it is literally impossible for a GMO to be a "man-made chemical" because, by definition, an organism is making it.
The gene comes from nature, not a lab.
Consider Golden Rice: a GMO where a bacterial gene for beta-carotene (a natural compound also found in carrots, and anything else orange) is put in rice.
If you ate rice and carrots, you would get the same nutrients as eating Golden Rice alone.
No difference in pesticides or insecticides.
Nothing your body cannot handle.
Nothing that could affect your gut bacteria at all.
So why be afraid?

You don't need any long-term studies to prove it is safe (though they are doing those right now anyway, and have already proven that the beta-carotene in Golden Rice is digested the same way as from any other source… and, yes, you can prove something like that).
In the end, you can eat whatever you like (most food poisoning is preventable when food is cooked well), and take anything that makes you feel healthier if you can afford to spend money on it.
Organic isn't bad for you, it just isn't good for you either.
All I wish is that one not buy into pseudoscience.
Before you say your diseases are caused by food, remember that correlation is not causality… as this tongue-in-cheek graph below should illustrate clearly.
I am not a regulatory expert, and if you really want to know, you should check the laws for ‘organic’ certification in your jurisdiction.
Generally, however, ‘organic’ livestock are raised with a pretty sensible approach to antibiotics—that is, if the livestock are sick, the disease may be diagnosed and then treated with antibiotics.
However, they are typically not allowed to use antibiotics in the way ‘conventional’ factory farms use it, i.e.
chronically, to avoid infection; and subclinically in the feed, to make the livestock grow faster.
Those are terrible ideas.

We know that excessive use of antibiotics tends to promote resistance in bacteria, so the routine use of antibiotics absent specific conditions to treat is a sort of large-scale project to breed better, stronger bacteria and render our antibiotics useless, in order to make more money in the short term.
I have my issues with the ‘organic’ movement, but the use of prophylactic antibiotics is a senseless, greedy evil that in the long term endangers both our health and the health of the meat industry.
There is no difference in quality or nutritional content between GMO, organic or commercial foods.
There is no difference in quality or nutritional content between GMO, organic or commercial foods.
There is no difference in quality or nutritional content between GMO, organic or commercial foods.
It’s all marketing.
Different varieties possibly make a difference.
tl;dr: Absolutely on meat and eggs, possibly on dairy products, probably not on vegetables, and no way in hell on TV dinners.
"Organic" is, unfortunately, something of a misnomer at this point.

The federal rules for "organic" allow all sorts of dubious behavior, while prohibiting the use of "organic" labels on foods that are actually better and more nutritious because they can't comply with rules designed for vast agribusinesses.
An organic vegetable is largely indistinguishable from a conventionally-grown one.
It's still grown in vast monocultures, far away from where you live, in varieties designed to ship well and look like a Platonic ideal of the vegetable.
They are still subjected to pesticides and fertilizers.

The "natural" nature of the fertilizers may give them a faint chance of being more tasty than those grown with chemical fertilizers (which are reductionist and may deprive plants of some things they need to develop full flavor), but I suspect few people can spot the difference.
However, many people prefer them for non-taste reasons.
The pesticides they're subjected to are less effective, so they need to use more rotation and other techniques to avoid predators.
This dumps less dangerous pesticides into the environment and may be safer for workers.
If you want better flavor, however, you pick vegetable varieties grown to taste good rather than to ship.
That usually means eating locally, which implies seasonally.
It's also unlikely to be organic, since that would forbid ever using any chemical fertilizers or pesticides, leaving land fallow for years that local farmers can't afford.
But it's going to be tastier, and probably healthier despite the occasional use of chemical pesticides (if done judiciously).
The differences with animal products are more noticeable.
Animals packed in conventionally have to be given huge amounts of antibiotics to keep them from dying.
These crowded conditions yield bland meat and eggs, and are an ethical nightmare.
They have to be fed a slightly more diverse range of foods to keep them healthy.
But the food is still limited in variety, and the difference between the "organically" grown mass-produced grain and conventional is probably undetectable.
You will notice the difference with eggs, absolutely.
The meat will be slightly more flavorful.
It should be noticeable in milk, but organic milk is generally subjected to a different pasteurization process.
The difference in processes will make a more noticeable flavor change than the underlying product.
The more processed the food is, the less the difference matters because it's been so thoroughly modified from its original state.
An organic TV dinner tastes of "processed" rather than "organic".
An organic TV dinner tastes of "processed" rather than "organic".
As before, cooking it yourself (or having it cooked fresh) will make a bigger difference.

Most people who eat organic food don't see it as a craze, but as an action that contributes to a better and healthier environment.
Food grown and raised to be certified as organic has been grown without the use of pesticides, herbicides or synthetic fertilisers.
Growing food this way means fewer pesticides, herbicides and chemicals find their way into what we eat and into our soils and rivers, kill our bees, etc.
Growing food this way means fewer pesticides, herbicides and chemicals find their way into what we eat and into our soils and rivers, kill our bees, etc.
That is better for us, and better for the environment - organic methods improve the soil, they don't diminish it.
That is better for us, and better for the environment - organic methods improve the soil, they don't diminish it.
There is some (limited) evidence that organic food is more nutritious but it is certainly the case that eating organic helps the body eliminate potential toxins.

Most people would argue that organic food tastes better too.
So, the main reasons people seek out organic food are health, environmental concerns, a desire to support more sustainable forms of agriculture and taste.

There are some disadvantages to eating organic food.

A big one is the cost, which is high because growing and raising organic food requires expensive accreditation, can be more labour-intensive, have lower crop yields (albeit of superior produce) and usually have poorer access to food distribution networks, increasing freight charges.

We need to find a balance between giant monocultures and small-scale, inefficient farming methods if we are going to feed the world properly.

Sustainable is not always efficient.
Conventional is often cheaper/more efficient because of higher yield.

Example: if I maximize my fertilizer inputs, plant herbicide resistant corn, and spray herbicides/insecticides to control weeds and pests I will have a significantly higher yield per acre than an organic field that does not receive these inputs.
That may not be the most sustainable because of increased nutrient runoff risks, pesticide drift, etc.

Often the higher price for organic food is because yield is reduced, increased labor inputs, organic fertilizer is more expensive than conventional, and people are willing to pay a premium for the organic certification at the store.

Not only are organic farms typically smaller than conventional ones, but they also, on average, take more time to produce crops because they refrain from using the chemicals and growth hormones used by conventional farmers.

Now, to your oft repeated assertion that all vegetables are the same.
This is true, if you manage to buy both a conventionally grown, and organically grown beefsteak tomato.
Accounting for other minor variations in terroir, the only consistent difference will be detectably more nitrogen in the conventional tomato.

That's a virtue of this thing called bio accumulation, and it's one of the contributing reasons organic produce is on the average more nutritious than the competitive goods offered on the shelf next to it.
They will often taste better too.
The market data is that you won't often find the exact same variety of most common vegetables grown both ways in the same market.
So you're right about organics being a marketing play.

Organic farmers aren't stupid (by and large) so they play to the brand they've collectively established by offering a differentiated high value product to compete with the cookie cutter burp less cucumbers and beefsteak tomatoes.
It's just good marketing.
Organic philosophy pushes older less 'optimized' species.
Conventional farming pushes the species that results in the highest mass yield per input.
The result is a beefsteak tomato today that has about 50% the nutrients value of a Brandywine or German Johnson.
They're also more visually appealing in during a period where preferences run toward the unfamiliar and unique.
There's also this whole dialogue about making an attempt at being responsible stewards of the earth, something Organics make a best effort at and evolve as research does.

And, while both sides of the coin have their high impact extremists, using that basis to deride an entire group is insulting to the other 98% of growers making an effort to counter the problems developed over a few generstions of unsustainable practices.

Fascinating question.

First off, one has to point out that there isn't actually too little food being produced globally (at least right now), it's just that it's in the wrong places, a lot is being wasted, and yet more is in relatively inefficient forms (like meat).

Most starving people actually being in Africa as of today and the most significant increase in population driving the demand for more calories being there as well, the first objective for Africa will be to feed itself.
But in theory, it probably could.
Africa has a lot of untapped potential in agriculture: There are significant productivity reserves.

Take as an example this study by the Ghanaian ministry of agriculture that tallies the average crop yields across the country under rainfed conditions: Notice that for the majority of the crops, production per hectare could be doubled, tripled, even quadrupled, and that is not taking into account any heavy technical input (six tonnes of maize per hectare is just over the global yield average, but the most advanced countries like the US, France or Italy average 9 or 10, and the recordholder in Iowa apparently reached yields of over 20).
And this is in a country like Ghana that is not the one with the least developed agriculture.

So on average, yields could be pushed up significantly, and Africa as a whole could probably double or triple its production with its current cultivated surface by changing and intensifying its methods.
There is a lot of non-cultivated, arable land.
This of course depends on the country even more heavily than the yields - a relatively small but super-densely populated country like Rwanda doesn't have much space left.
The Congo has lots.
It's rather likely that over the entire continent on average, you could increase cultivated surfaces by something like 100%.
Combine that with our previous assumption of productivity increases, it means Africa could produce four to six times more than it currently does.
There is no mechanisation.

Now, the impact there is not so much the yield per hectare as the yield per farmer and hence isn't necessarily a priority, or even a good thing, as long as there are plenty of people around to do the farming and aren't really qualified to do anything else; But as the next step, it could probably add a bit on top, let's say 25%, bringing the total increase to five to seven times the current production.
At this point, we haven't quite made a hard choice between organic and conventional methods.

By default, they are less aggressive to the environment in small farms in Africa simply because these farmers don't have the money to put the large quantities of fertiliser on their crops the Americans or Europeans do.

A meta study by UC Berkeley on the yields of organic agriculture vs. conventional agriculture found that the average difference across all the crops they looked at was around 19% (in favour of conventional), but also noted that a lot of the studies analysed were biased in favour of it and that certain practices, specifically multi-cropping and crop rotation, which happen to be common in most of African smallholder agriculture, can reduce the gap to less than 10%.
That's not that much, and given the potential increase we just found, the lower yield of organic farming doesn't actually make a huge difference.
So theoretically Africa should be able to become the breadbasket of the world (or at least of itself, for a start).
Production is not the only issue though: Logistics need to be taken care of.

Due to bad roads and an atomised, unorganised transportation market with not always reliable suppliers, it's not that easy and often expensive and risky to actually bring crops to the seaports for export.
Standards and norms.

To export to Europe for example, you need certifications proving the quality of your production processes and those are often too expensive and too complicated especially for small farmers to acquire.
This is only going to get more difficult as other geographies will continuously tighten their quality requirements as well.
The exporters have few direct links to the producers, leading to unstable supply and frequent over- or under-supply of various crops due to lack of communication and stable links.
Pre-processing and/or packaging.
This is essential for African countries to capture more value and should help with the linkage gap.

The OP is asking the wrong question.
There is absolutely no direct health impact to GMO consumption, and the government has no business either supporting or fighting it.

The government's job is to regulate the industry to prevent the loss of control of modified genes, and the funding of research and distribution of information so consumers like the OP stop worrying that somehow GMO foods are magically dangerous, where the cultivated crops they derive from and which, through artificial selection, or FAR more different genetically from wild stocks than the GMOs are from them, somehow aren't.

Let me give the disclaimer that if money and accessibility were no issue, I would buy absolutely everything organic, fair-trade, and local.
But that's not the case, and we have to make choices.
I do agree with grains not being as critical in the spectrum of organic.

Any fruits or vegetables that I peel before eating: Bananas, oranges, avocados, I feel OK about choosing non-organic.

Likewise, there is more to the picture of disease than what you can see and feel.
Those are subclinical problems, the most popular being cancer, which from a single cell takes 5 to 8 years to slowly grow with no symptoms detectable using "early detection".
For that whole time the patient would have had no idea they were sick.
You can also take an action that is in the direction of health, but have no perceivable clue how that is benefiting you.

I work in cancer PREVENTION advocacy, so I notice, when people are helped to avoid having problems in the first place (prevention), they forget the gravity of what they are avoiding because they can't feel it.
How wonderful does a life without cancer feel?
You are probably reading this not having a cancer (I hope), so pretty much all or most your life it felt like that?
Just normal, so why bother doing something (preventive) that keep things in a way that feels not particularly special?

(That was the evil cancer voice in people's heads by the way) But someone who had cancer and is cured will obviously feel the difference from getting back to normal and will be willing to make changes and efforts to keep it that way, the normal way.
It's a mental bias we have I suppose.

Let me quote from my previous answer Deekshith Pinto's answer to Can India afford organic farming?

As we all know, for a technique to be proven sustainable and for the state policy to be driven in that direction, the environmental, social as well as the economic sustainability needs to be demonstrated.
Let us see them one by one:There is no questions about the environmental sustainability of organic farming.

The chemical fertilizers and pesticides have cascading impacts on the ecological resilience of any region by killing many essential creatures apart from impacts on the human health, poisoning water and land, degrading the fertility, and so on.
Even during production these chemicals possess a huge carbon and water footprint, disrupts nitrogen and phosphate cycles, and pollutes local environment.
The organic farming techniques have proven to be of far less harm to the environment and human health.
The socio-economic dimension, on the other hand, is quite tricky.
Here comes the concepts like natural justice, intra- or inter-generational equity, precautionary principle, etc.
With current state of technology, yes, organic farming is comparatively costlier and gives less output.

Mind you, even these stats vary quite considerably depending on the scale, region, farming practices, etc., and sometimes it has been even demonstrated that organic farming can also be more profitable than inorganic.
However, given the current policy regime of subsidized chemical fertilizers and pesticides and the lack of awareness towards the nuanced techniques of organic farming, it does become less profitable.

However, what most of the land users (farmers) fail to recognize is the masking effect of the chemical fertilizers and pesticides on the continued degradation of their own land leading them towards a vicious circle where these chemicals degrades land productivity and the farmers apply even more chemicals to increase productivity.
At one point the economic viability of inorganic farming also diminishes as the land degrades more and more.
Therefore, it is always beneficial for the farmers to turn to organic farming in the long run, though it might mean less profits in the present circumstance.

The small land holders who live on a season to season basis might find it difficult due to the economy of scales but the medium and large scale farmers must shift to organic farming for their ow interest as well as for the benefit of the society.

The difference is though that “better for the environment” is far less BS than “it’s healthier” – because in its actual sense “organic” does mean “better for the environment” while it doesn’t mean “healthier” in its actual sense.
It did mean “healthier” around 20 years ago, at least in Europe.
But the pesticides that were used for “non-organic” food are now banned, so that difference is gone.
Unfortunately, the question from the start is problematic, because "sustainable" is difficult to define.
"Organic" farming and "regular" farming are also difficult to define.
But to provide my (biased) opinion, the answer is no.
My basic reason is that regular farming can incorporate all the techniques that organic farming employs, plus more .
Organic farming, by the certification definition, is restricted to the use of certain techniques.
On the more general point, the most important concept to think of when considering sustainability is that it's an incorporation of long-term and scalable economic, social, and environmental aspects.
All three are equally important.
A good example of why a discussion needs to consider all these points: organic yields and conventional yields do not differ per se .
But organic yields, when considering labour input, is always substantially less.
In my opinion, that fails the economic scalability test.

This is a good question and depends on the US definition of Organic wine.
There are two types in the US.
Wine Made With Organic Grapes and 100% Organic wine(USDA Organic).
The first category is (As it's wording states) made from organic certified grapes but not made with organic principles in the cellar.
The main point of differentiation to consumers is that sulphur dioxide is allowed to be added, with a maximum of 100 Parts per Million.
Though i have to point out that there is no control of this limit at all with either the US government or producing country, in the case of imported wines.
So these wines can fluctuate easily well above 100 ppm.
The total Sulfite level in the finished wine has to be under 10 Parts per Million and no other Non Organic ingredients are allowed.
This category of wine has to under go USDA Lab analysis every vintage to prove it is what it claims.
Of course like all marketeers we think the best Organic wines are the ones we import and distribute through out the US.

A statistical fact that is true about a large set may not be true about a subset.
For example, the majority of Americans may vote for Obama, but the majority of voters in a particular state X may vote for his opponent.
So if the questions is about state X, the answer should also be about state X, and not about a larger set consisting of 49 other states.

An excerpt for your purposes from our guide is as follows (from an Australian perspective): Difference Between Organic and Natural - Easy Guide - Nim-Véda Australia Blog It turns out that in Australia at least, Certified Organic refers to products that are Organic and have been declared as such by an appropriate government/independent body.

Acquiring Organic Certification is not a small feat, it takes loads of time, lots of documentation, going back and forth a gazillion times and heaps of finance.
Organic is probably (don’t shoot me, I did say probably and even italicised it) exactly the same in terms of quality and processing as Certified Organic without the official badge of honour.
What stops some people from purchasing organic however is that there’s no official proof.
It’s like swearing that you saw a spaceship without the photograph to prove it.
You may be wondering why I’ve italicised official twice before.

It’s because the manufacturers of Organic Products should have some sort of documentation stating that the products have had no chemical and unnatural processing going on before it got to your fingertips.
Should doesn’t always mean they do, which is wrong.
At least in my book anyway but we all have different yardsticks … you get the picture.

Though there’s no official certification, the document stating the above still means the manufacturer better be telling the truth or they’re likely to be in hot water if someone finds out otherwise.

The fundamental principal of organic farming is to produce crops without using chemicals, GMO seeds, or otherwise compromising the yield of the crop so that it is as natural as possible.
Often, this means using manual labor and symbiotic methods for control of insects, weeds, and disease, and organic fertilizer rather than chemical products.
Using natural selection seeds/cultivars, and preventing cross-pollination with non organic crops to insure the harvest produce is not adulterated with non organic produce.

You will want to educate yourself on creating compost for a nutrient rich amendment for your soil.

The idea is to identify the culprit and use the appropriate defense as you see it.
This is opposed to the modern practices of commercial growing that favors indiscriminate and broad spectrum killers as a prevention.
It is about balance, when you have found that, the world wins.

From Wikipedia: In 1939, Lord Northbourne coined the term organic farming in his book Look to the Land (1940), out of his conception of "the farm as organism," to describe a holistic, ecologically-balanced approach to farming—in contrast to what he called chemical farming , which relied on "imported fertility" and "cannot be self-sufficient nor an organic whole."
This is different from the scientific use of the term "organic," to refer to a class of molecules that contain carbon, especially those involved in the chemistry of life.
...For the vast majority of human history, agriculture can be described as organic; only during the 20th century was a large supply of new synthetic chemicals introduced to the food supply.
The organic farming movement arose in the 1940s in response to the industrialization of agriculture."
